title: Catching Some Z's : Z-Scores That Is!
question_text:
Exhausted Emily finally got a good night sleep last night! The number of hours that she slept corresponds to a $z$-score of $1.5$.
What is the proper interpretation of this $z$-score?

choices.text: Emily slept $1.5$ hours more than usual last night.
The number of hours that Emily slept last night was $1.5$ times the median number of hours of sleep that she gets.
About $93\%$ of the time, Emily gets less sleep than she got last night.
The number of hours of sleep that Emily got last night was $1.5$ standard deviations above the mean number of hours of sleep that she gets.
Emily got $1.5$ hours of sleep last night.

solution:
A $z$-score tells us how many standard deviations an observation is above or below the mean. If the observation is above the mean, the $z$-score will be positive while an observation below the mean will have a negative $z$-score. Emily's $z$-score is positive, so Choice 'D' is the proper interpretation of the $z$-score.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect. A $z$-score does not measure how many additional hours of sleep Emily got.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. A $z$-score does not indicate that the median would be multiplied by the $z$-score.

Choice 'C' is a correct statement (assuming the distribution of Emily's sleep times is approximately normal). However, it is not a correct interpretation of the $z$-score.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. A $z$-score does not provide an actual value for the number of hours of sleep. It would be very sad and perhaps dangerous if $1.5$ hours of sleep corresponded to a $z$-score of $1.5$! That would mean that the average number of hours of sleep that Emily gets is less than $1.5$ hours.
